choices.text: She is susceptible to chicken pox
She is immune to chicken pox

questions.text: A pregnant woman residing in the same house as her niece, who has contracted Varicella, received a negative result in her test for serum antibodies against varicella. What implications can be drawn from this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) She is susceptible to chicken pox

 

Anti-Varicella/Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)/Chickenpox IgG; Varicella immunity test

 

  • Negative: Indicates no detectable Varicella IgG antibodies. A negative results indicate no current or previous infection with Varicella virus. Such individuals are presumed to be susceptible to primary infection.
  • Equivocal: Equivocal results are indeterminate. Patient may or may not have immunity to Varicella Virus. It is not acceptable proof of immunity.
  • Positive: Indicates evidence of Varicella IgG antibodies and suggests past or current infection with Varicella virus. Antibodies obtained via acquired immunity or immunization and probable protection from clinical infection. (Immunity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. She is immune to zoster: Incorrect. Immunity to zoster (shingles) comes from having had a previous varicella (chicken pox) infection or vaccination. A negative antibody test indicates she has not had varicella.

 

Option B. She is susceptible to zoster: Incorrect. Susceptibility to zoster (shingles) typically arises from a reactivation of the varicella virus in individuals who have previously had chicken pox. A negative test means she has not had chicken pox, so she cannot develop zoster but is susceptible to chicken pox.

 

Option D. She is immune to chicken pox: Incorrect. A negative antibody test indicates she does not have immunity to chicken pox.
 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative test result for serum antibodies against varicella indicates that the individual is susceptible to chicken pox, as there are no detectable antibodies suggesting past infection or vaccination.

questions.text: You're rotating in the infection control unit of a tertiary care hospital in Chennai. As part of your duties, you have been assigned to educate the staff about the importance of precautionary measures and isolation techniques for various conditions. While discussing droplet precautions, one of the staff inquired about the diseases for which such precautions are necessary. Which of the following conditions does NOT typically require precautionary measures and isolation due to droplet infection? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Localized varicella zoster

 

  • Droplet precautions and isolation are unnecessary for localized varicella-zoster, as this virus is exclusively transmitted through direct contact.
  • When varicella-zoster remains confined to a patient with a fully functioning immune system and can be effectively contained or covered, there is no need for droplet precautions.
  • However, if varicella becomes disseminated in any patient, it necessitates both airborne and contact precautions.
  • On the other hand, diseases like diphtheria, pertussis, and mycoplasma are transmitted via droplets and, therefore, demand droplet precautions and isolation measures.
  • These precautions include the use of masks, gowns, gloves, and protective eye gear when delivering direct patient care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pertussis: Requires droplet precautions due to transmission via respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Diphtheria: Requires droplet precautions as it is spread through respiratory droplets.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma pneumonia: Requires droplet precautions due to transmission via respiratory droplets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Localized varicella zoster does not require droplet precautions as it is transmitted through direct contact, while conditions like pertussis, diphtheria, and mycoplasma pneumonia require droplet precautions due to their transmission via respiratory droplets.

questions.text: During your clinical rotation in infectious diseases, a patient with dengue fever develops warning signs like abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, clinical fluid accumulation, and an increase in hematocrit with a decrease in platelet count. Which of the following is the cornerstone of management for a patient showing warning signs of dengue? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) IV Fluids 

 

  • The mainstay treatment for patients with dengue showing warning signs is intravenous (IV) fluid therapy.
  • This approach is crucial to prevent progression to severe dengue, including dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) and dengue shock syndrome (DSS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelets: Only indicated if there is severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm³) with active bleeding.

 

Option C. Cryoglobulins: Not relevant for dengue management.

 

Option D. FFP (Fresh Frozen Plasma): Not a primary treatment for dengue with warning signs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In the 18th century, the East India Company engaged in the illicit trade of a specific substance with China, which played a significant role in the historical trade dynamics. What was the substance that the company smuggled into China during this time? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Opium

 

Explanation:

 

  • In 18th & 19th centuaries, EIC (East India Company) used to purchase Tea against Silver. 
  • By opium export, EIC were able to save their Silver and purchased tea against Opium.
  • Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cannabis: Marijuana, a psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Option D. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China .

questions.text: A 32-year-old man visits your clinic with his 2-year-old son, expressing concerns about vaccinations due to a belief in his community that vaccinations can lead to impotency. He is fearful for his son's future but is also influenced by societal beliefs. Addressing his concerns requires overcoming which type of barrier? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cultural barrier

 

The wrong belief of vaccination leading to impotency is an example of cultural barrier. Cultural barrier includes illiteracy, knowledge and understanding, customs, beliefs, religion, economic and social class differences, language variations, and cultural difficulties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psychological barrier occurs due to emotional disturbances, levels of intelligence, language or comprehension difficulties.

 

Option B. Environmental barriers include noise, congestion etc. in the external environment which hampers understanding and communication.

 

Option C. Physiological barriers include difficulties in hearing, expression, vision etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cultural beliefs can significantly influence health decisions, and understanding these beliefs is crucial for effective healthcare communication and intervention.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to an antenatal clinic at PHC and gives a history of Diabetes in her mother. Diabetic screening is carried out for this pregnant woman at
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24-28 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Diabetic screening in pregnant women, especially those with a family history of diabetes, is typically performed between 24 to 28 weeks of gestation. This period is chosen because it is when insulin resistance usually begins to increase due to hormonal changes in pregnancy. The screening is done using the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) to confirm gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diabetic screening for pregnant women is best performed between 24-28 weeks of gestation using the oral glucose tolerance test to diagnose gestational diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: An individual seeks to explore the correlation between smoking and lung cancer. To do so, they gather information on individuals diagnosed with lung cancer from government hospitals, along with data on the quantity of cigarette packets sold during the corresponding timeframe. What category of study does this represent? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ecological

 

In the given study, the unit of study is the population, and the data collected by the investigator is secondary in nature. Therefore, this type of study is an ecological study, also known as a correlational study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cross-Sectional Study: Involves collecting data at a single point in time from individuals to assess the prevalence of an outcome or characteristic.

 

  • The unit of analysis is the individual, not the population.

 

Option C. Experimental Study: Involves the researcher manipulating one or more variables to observe the effect on an outcome.

 

  • There is no experimental intervention in the given study scenario.

 

Option D. Quasi-Experimental Study: Involves an intervention but lacks random assignment of participants to treatment or control groups.

 

  • Similar to experimental studies, quasi-experimental studies involve individuals, not population-level data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ECOLOGICAL STUDY / CO-RELATIONAL STUDY

 

  • Done at a point of time [E.g. in 2023]
  • Used in Nutritional surveys, e.g. à Avg. fat intake = 20gm/day
  • Can’t calculate strength of Association or Prevalence
  • Based on secondary data [collected by someone else, studied by investigator]

questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Recommended dietary allowance

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population. RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population. RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adequate intake: A value based on observed or experimentally determined approximations of nutrient intake by a group (or groups) of healthy people.

 

Option B. Dietary goals: are quantitative national targets for selected macronutrients and micronutrients aimed at preventing long-term chronic disease. They focus on population-level nutritional health.

 

Option C. The estimated average requirement (EAR): Average daily level of intake estimated to meet the requirements of 50% of healthy individual’s RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)

 

  • Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population
  • RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population
  • RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research
  • RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness
  • RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement
  • RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable.
  • For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.

questions.text: Imagine a scenario where a novel medication is introduced that significantly reduces mortality from a specific disease but does not actually cure the disease. As patients continue to live longer with the disease due to this medication, it would have an effect on the epidemiological metrics. Which of the following statements correctly describes the expected change in prevalence and incidence as a result of this medication? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase in prevalence

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a drug which can reduce mortality but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in incidence: Incorrect, as the medication does not affect the rate at which new cases occur.

 

Option B. Decrease in prevalence: Incorrect, since patients living longer with the disease will increase prevalence.

 

Option C. Increase in incidence: Incorrect, because incidence measures new cases, not the duration or survival of existing cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

choices.text: Take mother's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion
Take Husband's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion
Take mother's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion
Take Husband's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion

questions.text: Under MTP Act guidelines, to terminate Meningomyelocele fetus at 21 weeks POG (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Take mother's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act guidelines in India, termination of pregnancy is permitted up to 24 weeks of gestation.

 

This is divided into two categories: low-risk (up to 20 weeks) and high-risk (20-24 weeks).

 

In the case of a high-risk pregnancy, such as terminating a fetus with meningomyelocele at 21 weeks of gestation, the opinion of two doctors is required.

 

Additionally, as per the MTP Act, only the mother's consent is necessary for the termination of pregnancy, and no consent is required from the spouse or husband.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Take mother's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion - This option is incorrect because terminating a pregnancy between 20-24 weeks requires the opinion of two doctors, not just one.

 

Option B. Take Husband's consent and 1 Doctor's opinion - This option is incorrect because the husband's consent is not required under the MTP Act, and the opinion of two doctors is necessary for a high-risk pregnancy termination.

 

Option D. Take Husband's consent and 2 Doctors' opinion - While this option correctly states the requirement of two doctors' opinions, it is incorrect because the husband's consent is not needed under the MTP Act.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the MTP Act guidelines in India, terminating a fetus with meningomyelocele at 21 weeks of gestation requires the mother's consent and the opinion of two doctors.

questions.text: For which medical condition is the provided drug typically recommended? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Malaria

 

The picture depicts artemisin-based combination therapy (ACT). This medicine is used to treat falciparum malaria.

 

ARTEMISINS - Artesunate and Artemether

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

Artemisin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only

 

Educational Objective:

 

Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT), is typically recommended for the treatment of falciparum malaria.

questions.text:
To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, what level should the rate of couple protection exceed? [NEET PG 2018]

 

(NRR: Net reproduction rate)
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 60% 

 

The Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) is a measure of the average number of daughters a woman would have if she passed through her lifetime conforming to the age-specific fertility and mortality rates of a given year. An NRR of 1 means that each woman is, on average, having one daughter who survives to reproductive age, thereby replacing herself without population growth or decline.

 

To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) must exceed 60%. This aligns with the scenario where every couple has two children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, the rate of couple protection should exceed 60%. This level of contraceptive use helps in maintaining a stable population by ensuring that each woman, on average, has one daughter who survives to reproductive age.

questions.text: Instilling a particular idea in people’s mind and not affecting their thought process is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Health Propaganda

 

Health propaganda is a method of communication aimed at instilling a particular idea or belief in people's minds without engaging their thought process. Unlike health education, which appeals to reason and encourages reflective thinking and skill development, health propaganda is more emotion-driven and does not foster independent thought or critical analysis. The objective is to influence behavior quickly and effectively, often without the support of scientific evidence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Health Awareness: This involves disseminating information to make people aware of health issues, but it does not necessarily instil a specific idea nor does it bypass the thought process.

 

Option C. Health Education: Health education involves a reasoned approach where individuals are informed and encouraged to think critically about health-related issues. It promotes reflective behavior and skill development.

 

Option D. Health Promotion: This is a broader concept that encompasses health education and activities aimed at improving overall health, but it does not specifically focus on instilling ideas without thought.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Health Education versus Propaganda/Publicity

choices.text: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure
Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.text: A boys' hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Isolate for 6 days

 

The given scenario points to the diagnosis of chickenpox.

 

In a boys' hostel, everyone is not in the high-risk groups for severe varicella infection. For the management of suspected cases in this situation, isolation for 6 days from the onset of the rash is the appropriate measure to prevent further spread of the infection. Acyclovir and ZIG are not necessary for healthy individuals.

 

Varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is indicated as prophylaxis for individuals at high risk like Immunocompromised individuals, Pregnant women and Newborns.

 

 

 

Note –

 

Acyclovir: Antiviral treatment with acyclovir is generally reserved for high-risk groups or severe cases.

 

VZIG (Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin): VZIG is indicated for individuals at high risk of severe varicella infection, such as immunocompromised individuals, pregnant women, and newborns. It is not routinely given to healthy individuals in a setting like a boys' hostel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For managing a chickenpox outbreak in a boys' hostel, the best step is to isolate affected individuals for 6 days from the onset of the rash. This helps prevent the spread of the virus. Antiviral treatments and immunoglobulins are reserved for high-risk individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following best represents the primary concern addressed by the POCSO Act? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Child sexual abuse

 

  • The POCSO Act (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act) 2012 is designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse and exploitation.
  • It includes provisions for punishment of various offenses such as penetrative sexual assault, aggravated penetrative sexual assault, sexual assault, aggravated sexual assault, sexual harassment, and the use of children for pornography.
  • The act ensures stringent punishment for offenders to provide a safe and secure environment for children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Women empowerment: Incorrect. The POCSO Act is focused on protecting children from sexual offenses, not specifically on women empowerment.

 

Option B. Human trafficking: Incorrect. While important, human trafficking is not the primary focus of the POCSO Act.

 

Option C. Juvenile delinquency: Incorrect. The act deals with protecting children from sexual offenses, not addressing juvenile delinquency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POCSO Act (Prevention of Children from Sexual Offences Act) 2012

 

  • Child definition: Any person less than 18 years of age
  • Includes: Sexual abuses and pornography
  • Punishments under the act:

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended to be done till what age of the child? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 months

 

In India, exclusive breastfeeding is recommended until the baby is 6 months old, compared to 4 months in developed countries.

 

Breastfeeding should continue until the child is 2 years old in India and 1 year in developed countries.

 

Points to remember:

 

  • Breast milk provides about 65 kilocalories and 0.9 to 1.1 grams of protein per 100 ml.
  • Rich in immunoglobulin A, crucial for the infant’s immune development, along with other immunoglobulins.
  • Contains essential fatty acids like docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and taurine, both important for brain development.
  • Higher levels of lactose, iron, and water in breast milk compared to cow's milk, with better calcium to phosphorus ratio.
  • Iron in breast milk has high absorption; though calcium is lower, its absorption is high.
  • Casein to whey ratio is less than 1, beneficial for infants.
  • Initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth: within one hour after vaginal delivery and four hours after cesarean section, ideally at the delivery table.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first 6 months of life to ensure the best possible health outcomes for the child.

choices.text: From onset of rash to 3 days after rash
2 weeks before rash to 1 week after rash
From onset of rash to 5 days after rash
From catarrhal stage to 4 days after rash

questions.text: In a busy OPD at a District hospital, you are evaluating a 5-year-old boy who presents with fever, generalized malaise, and a distinctive rash. The child's clinical presentation strongly suggests a diagnosis of measles. The mother, anxious about the contagious nature of the disease and the risk it poses to her other kids and family members, inquires about the recommended period of isolation for her infected child. What would be your most appropriate recommendation for the duration of isolation? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) From catarrhal stage to 4 days after rash

 

  • Patient should be advised to stay in isolation from onset of catarrhal stage to 3rd/4th day of rash.
  • Isolation is the separation for the period of communicability, of infected persons from others in such places/conditions as to prevent/limit transmission to those susceptible.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In analyzing the demographic data of a nation as depicted in a population pyramid, which statement incorrectly reflects the implications of birth rates and life expectancy shown in the pyramid? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Developed countries

 

The pyramid shows a broader base indicating a higher proportion of young people, which is characteristic of developing countries with higher birth rates and typically shorter life expectancies. This contradicts the assumption that it represents a developed country.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased Population: This could potentially be true for a developing country with high birth rates, but the statement itself does not align directly with the pyramid's implications without additional demographic growth rate data.

 

Option B. More young Population:  This is true as the broader base indicates a larger proportion of young individuals.

 

Option C. Developing Countries: This is a correct identification, aligning with the pyramid's shape, which reflects typical characteristics of developing countries (broader base, younger population).

 

Additional Information

 

Utility of Population pyramid:

 

  • Shape of population pyramid indicates fertility pattern
    • Broad base, Narrow top (upright triangle): High proportion of younger population (developing countries)
    • Bulge in Middle, Spindle shape: High proportion of adults (developed countries)
  • Span (height) of population pyramid indicates life expectancy
    • Taller pyramid: Higher life expectancy (developed countries)
    • Shorter pyramid: Lower life expectancy (developing countries)
  • Symmetry of population pyramid indicates sex ratio
    • Symmetric pyramid: ideal sex ratio (developed countries)
    • Asymmetric pyramid: unfavourable sex ratio <1000 (developing countries)

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following calculates one variable using another variable? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of Regression

 

Coefficient of Regression can be used to calculate one variable using another variable.

 

The Coefficient of Regression is a statistical measure that assesses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. It is used to predict or estimate the value of one variable based on the value of another variable.

 

For example, in a regression analysis, we may want to predict a person's weight based on their height. In this case, height would be the independent variable and weight would be the dependent variable. The coefficient of regression would help us determine the relationship between these variables and enable us to make predictions about a person's weight based on their height.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Coefficient of Correlation:  Measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables.

 

Option C.  The Coefficient of Variation: Is a measure of the relative variability of a dataset.

 

Option D. The Coefficient of Determination: Is a measure that determines the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is explained by the independent variable in a regression analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Regression is used to calculate or predict the value of one variable based on the value of another variable, quantifying the relationship between the independent and dependent variables in regression analysis.

questions.text: Components of Disaster cycle that can be included in the recovery phase are: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Response – Rehabilitation – Reconstruction

 

 

The disaster cycle consists of several phases: impact, response, rehabilitation, reconstruction, mitigation, and preparedness.

 

The recovery phase specifically focuses on restoring the affected area to normalcy and includes three key components: Response, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction (Mnemonic: 3Rs). These steps are crucial for rebuilding after a disaster, addressing immediate needs (response), restoring essential services (rehabilitation), and rebuilding infrastructure (reconstruction).

 

Educational Objective:
 

The recovery phase of the disaster cycle includes the components of Response, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction, which are essential for restoring the community post-disaster.

questions.text: Number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group per year is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GFR

 

The General Fertility Rate (GFR) is a demographic measure that indicates the number of live births per 1,000 women of reproductive age (typically aged 15-49) in a given year. It is a more specific measure of fertility than the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) because it focuses only on women in their reproductive years rather than the entire population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TFR (Total Fertility Rate): This measure represents the average number of total children a woman would have during her entire reproductive lifespan (15-49 years), assuming she experiences the current age-specific fertility rates throughout her life.

 

Option B. GRR (Gross Reproduction Rate): GRR refers to the total number of daughters a woman would have during her reproductive life span, assuming no mortality and the current age-specific fertility rates.

 

Option C. NRR (Net Reproduction Rate): NRR is similar to GRR, but it accounts for mortality. It indicates the number of daughters a woman would have who would survive to the end of their reproductive period, given the current mortality rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The General Fertility Rate (GFR) is the number of live births per 1,000 women of reproductive age (15-49 years) in a given year, making it a key measure of fertility in a population.

 

Note –

 

  • TFR is also known as completed family size.
  • To achieve NRR 1, couple protection rate should be more than 60%, which is already achieved
  • Best contraceptive advisable is vasectomy (sterilization).
  • As per NFHS 5, TFR goal was 2.1, India have already achieved the replacement level (TFR 2)

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is considered the most sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community. IMR reflects the overall health and well-being of infants and the quality of maternal and infant care services. It is a comprehensive measure that can indicate various aspects of public health, including nutritional status, access to medical care, public health practices, and the socio-economic conditions of the community.

 

IMR = (Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total number of live births) × 1000.

 

SRS 2022-23 Latest data

choices.text: EBM mandates that clinical decisions should exclusively rely on findings from high-quality randomized controlled trials, disregarding other forms of evidence.
EBM categorically negates the intrinsic value of accumulated clinical experience, positioning empirical research findings as the sole determinant of clinical practice.
EBM harmoniously amalgamates the clinician's individual expertise, accrued through years of practice, with the most robust and relevant external scientific evidence.
EBM emphasizes a dependency on recommendations primarily made by pharmaceutical companies, given their investment in large-scale research.

questions.text: A recent medical graduate is attending a seminar on Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM). The speaker emphasizes EBM's integrative approach to patient care. Which statement most accurately encapsulates the core philosophy of EBM? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) EBM harmoniously amalgamates the clinician's individual expertise, accrued through years of practice, with the most robust and relevant external scientific evidence

 

  • It integrates individual clinical expertise with the best external clinical evidence.
  • EBM is a combination of research evidence, clinical experience, and patient values/preferences.

 

 

  • Critical appraisal of research findings and decisions regarding whether, and how, to use findings in the care of patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EBM mandates that clinical decisions should exclusively rely on findings from high-quality randomized controlled trials, disregarding other forms of evidence: Incorrect. EBM values a combination of different types of evidence, including clinical expertise and patient preferences.

 

Option B. EBM categorically negates the intrinsic value of accumulated clinical experience, positioning empirical research findings as the sole determinant of clinical practice: Incorrect. EBM values clinical experience alongside empirical research findings.

 

Option D. EBM emphasizes a dependency on recommendations primarily made by pharmaceutical companies, given their investment in large-scale research: Incorrect. EBM focuses on unbiased, high-quality evidence rather than recommendations from potentially biased sources.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The core philosophy of Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) is to integrate the clinician's expertise with the best available external evidence and patient values to make informed clinical decisions.

questions.text: As a researcher designing a clinical study, you are exploring methods to eliminate confounding variables, which can lead to spurious associations between the independent and dependent variables. Which of the following methods is NOT primarily used to eliminate confounders? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Blinding

 

  • This method is used primarily to prevent bias in the conduct and interpretation of clinical research.
  • Blinding can be of participants, investigators, or those assessing outcomes, to ensure that the behaviors and evaluations are not influenced by knowledge of which treatment or intervention participants receive.
  • While blinding reduces bias, it does not specifically address the issue of confounding variables.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Randomization: By randomly assigning participants to different groups in a study, randomization aims to evenly distribute confounding variables across all groups, thus reducing their potential impact on the outcome. This helps ensure that any differences observed between groups can more reliably be attributed to the intervention itself rather than to external variables.

 

Option C. Restriction: This involves limiting the participants in a study to certain criteria, effectively isolating specific characteristics and reducing variation that could lead to confounding. For example, a study may restrict participants to a certain age range, gender, or health status to control for these variables.

 

Option D. Matching: Matching involves pairing participants in the treatment group with similar participants in the control group based on certain characteristics (e.g., age, sex, baseline health status). This technique helps to ensure that the treatment and control groups are comparable on these characteristics, thereby controlling for confounding variables related to them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blinding is used to remove Bias.

 

Confounding can be removed by:

 

  1. Matching (MC used /simplest)
  2. Randomisation (2nd Best Method)
  3. Restriction
  4. Stratification
  5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)
  6. Stratified Randomization (Overall Best Method)

questions.text: While assessing children's nutritional status in a school, you come across a child with low height for age. What is this known as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stunting

 

Explanation:

 

Low height for age is referred to as stunting. Stunting is an indicator of chronic malnutrition, where the child's growth has been inhibited over a prolonged period.

 

Note – Stunting is also known as Dwarfism

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Underweight: Low weight for age is known as underweight. It can indicate acute on chronic malnutrition.

 

Option B. Wasting: Low weight for height is referred to as wasting. This indicates acute malnutrition, where there has been a significant recent weight loss. Wasting is also known as Emaciation.

 

Option C. Overweight: This indicates excess weight relative to height.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low height for age is known as stunting and indicates chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: You are counseling a new mother about the importance of immunization for her newborn. She is particularly interested in understanding the BCG vaccine's benefits, as she has heard conflicting opinions from friends and family. Based on current evidence and guidelines, which of the following best describes the primary protective effects of the BCG vaccine in the context of tuberculosis (TB)? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) CNS and disseminated TB 

 

  • BCG vaccine provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB.

 

BCG Vaccine

 

  • LIVE, Attenuated, Lyophilised vaccine
  • Reconstituent – NORMAL SALINE
  • Strain DANISH–1331 (VIA M. BOVIS, 239 SC FOR 13 YR)
  • Dose 0.05 (upto 28 days, then 0.1 ml) ID, just above insertion of left deltoid
  • Efficacy 0-80% (MEDIAN-50%)
  • Dose at birth, 1 TU in 0.1 ml
  • 20 years protection {No protection against pulmonary TB}

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BCG vaccine is primarily recommended for its effectiveness in preventing severe forms of tuberculosis, such as CNS and disseminated TB, in children.

questions.text: Bilirubin is measured as mg/dl in which scale? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous

 

Explanation:

 

Bilirubin is measured in milligrams per decilitre (mg/dl), which is a continuous scale. Continuous quantitative data, where multiple values can exist between any two given values, is measured on a continuous or metric scale.

 

Such as bilirubin levels of 4 mg/dl, 4.1 mg/dl, 4.25 mg/dl, 6 mg/dl, 7 mg/dl, 10 mg/dl, and 11.4 mg/dl, illustrate the continuous nature of the measurement, with numerous possible values between any two points.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ordinal: This option is incorrect because ordinal scales represent ordered categories or ranks. This is discrete data

 

Option B. Nominal: This option is incorrect because nominal scales represent categories or names without any inherent order or quantitative value. This is discrete data

 

Option C. Discrete: This option is incorrect because discrete scales involve counting or whole numbers, whereas bilirubin measurements can have fractional or decimal values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilirubin is measured in milligrams per decilitre (mg/dl), which falls under the continuous scale, as it allows for numerous possible values between any two given points, reflecting the precise quantitative nature of the measurement.

questions.text: Pneumoconiosis associated with exposure to cotton dust is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Byssinosis.

 

Byssinosis, also known as "brown lung disease," is a type of pneumoconiosis specifically associated with exposure to cotton dust. It is an occupational lung disease that typically affects workers in the textile industry, including those involved in spinning, weaving, and processing cotton. The inhalation of cotton dust can cause the airways to become constricted, leading to symptoms such as chest tightness, coughing, and wheezing, particularly at the start of the workweek, which is sometimes referred to as "Monday fever."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bagassosis: This is a pneumoconiosis caused by exposure to bagasse, the fibrous material left over after sugarcane or sorghum stalks are crushed to extract their juice. It is commonly seen in workers in the sugar industry.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Also known as "black lung disease," this condition is caused by the inhalation of coal dust. It primarily affects coal miners and results in the accumulation of carbon particles in the lungs.

 

Option D. Silicosis: Silicosis is caused by the inhalation of silica dust, which is commonly found in industries like cement, glass manufacturing, and stone cutting. It leads to inflammation and scarring in the lungs.

 

Note –

 

Asbestosis: Caused by exposure to asbestos dust, asbestosis is a serious condition that leads to lung fibrosis. It is prevalent among workers in the cement industry and is particularly noted in shipyard workers due to the historical use of asbestos in ship construction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

List of Pneumoconiosis:

choices.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter

questions.text: The most effective markers for air pollution surveillance include: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles

 

The best indicators for air pollution surveillance are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles.

 

  • Overall best Air Pollution Indicator - SO2
  • Overall best chemical Indicator of Air Pollution - SO2
  • Best biological Indicator of Air Pollution → LICHENS
  • Air Pollution Monitoring → CPCB [Central Pollution Control Board]

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective markers for air pollution surveillance include sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles. These provide a comprehensive assessment of air quality and are crucial for monitoring the impact on health and the environment.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to a health clinic with difficulty seeing in the evening and dry, irritated eyes. Her diet mainly consists of rice and lentils, with limited access to green leafy vegetables or animal products. On examination, dryness and Bitot's spots are noted on the conjunctiva. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for her symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vitamin A

 

Deficiency of Vitamin A leads to dryness of eyes or Xerophthalmia. The clinical presentation in the question aligns with the signs and symptoms of Vitamin A deficiency.

 

WHO Grading of Vitamin A Deficiency:

 

 

  • Xerophthalmia is most common in children aged 1 - 3 years
  • ‘First clinical sign’ of Vitamin-A deficiency: Conjunctival xerosis 
  • ‘First clinical symptom’ of Vitamin-A deficiency: Night blindness
  • Conjunctival xerosis in Xerophthalmia has a characteristic appearance of ‘emerging like sand banks at receding tide
  • Bitot’s Spots’ are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, foamy spots on bulbar conjunctiva, on either side of cornea; In young children they indicate Vitamin-A deficiency, whereas in adults they are often inactive sequelae of earlier disease

 

 

Image showing Bitot’s Spot

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency leads to Xerophthalmia, which presents with symptoms like dryness of eyes, night blindness, and Bitot's spots. This condition is common in children with diets lacking in vitamin A-rich foods.

questions.text: An orthopedic surgeon consults with a patient who recently lost both hands in an industrial accident, severely affecting his ability to perform daily tasks and work. Which term best categorizes the patient's condition given the profound impact on his life and role within society? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Handicap

 

The term "Handicap" most accurately describes the patient's condition. It refers to the disadvantage arising from an impairment or disability, which significantly limits the ability to fulfill roles or activities that are normally expected in society. Here, the loss of hands not only impacts physical capabilities but also severely hampers professional life and social roles, encompassing both the physical and socio-economic effects of the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disability: Any restriction or inability to perform an activity in a range considered normal for human being. (Inability to write and do machine work in this example)

 

Option B. Impairment: Any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological, anatomical structure or its function. (As loss of both the hands in this case)

 

Option C. Disease: Any abnormal condition of an organism that impairs function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Handicap: A disadvantage for a given individual resulting from an impairment or disability that limits/ prevents fulfilment of a role considered normal for that individual. (Loss of job in this example)

questions.text: A laboratory technician is analyzing cell populations using flow cytometry. This technique allows for the simultaneous multiparametric analysis of the physical and/or chemical characteristics of single cells flowing through an optical and/or electronic detection apparatus. Which visual depictions are commonly generated in flow cytometry for the evaluation of these cell populations? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Histogram, dot plot

 

  • Histogram and Dot plot can be used to depict flow cytometry analysis.
  • Histogram can be used to compare single parameter (1D)

 

 

 Scatter/Dot plot are used to compare 2 or 3 parameters (2D; 3D)

 

 

Flow Cytometry is used to detect and measure physical and chemical characteristics of a population of cells or parameters like cell counting, sorting, detect microorganisms, detect neoplasm and various more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In flow cytometry, histograms and dot plots are the common visual depictions for evaluating cell populations.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the point from A to C in the given flowchart depicting the natural history of a disease? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lead time

 

Lead time is defined as the interval between the point a condition is detected through screening and the Time it would normally have been detected due to appearance and reporting of signs and symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening time:  This term refers to the period during which screening tests are conducted to detect disease in asymptomatic individuals.

 

Option C. Lag time:  This term is generally used to describe a delay between the onset of an event and its detection or measurement. In the context of disease, lag time could refer to the delay between symptom onset and diagnosis.

 

Option D. Generation time:  This term is typically used in epidemiology to describe the time interval between the infection of a host and the subsequent transmission of the disease to another host. It does not relate to the timeline of diagnosis within an individual patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead time is the interval between the detection of a disease through screening and its usual time of diagnosis due to symptom presentation.

 

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening (leading the time of diagnosis)

 

Early detection of disease due to screening (B rather than C) will ensure earlier institution of treatment, thus better prognosis.

questions.text:
The table provided illustrates a multivariate analysis assessing the relationship between the risk of blindness and various factors including age, literacy rate, place of residence, and gender. Which of the subsequent statements accurately interprets this data? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

 

  1. Female population is at greater risk of developing blindness.
  2. People dwelling in rural areas are at increased risk of developing blindness.
  3. Risk of developing blindness increases with age.
  4. Illiteracy leads to increased risk of developing blindness.
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 3 and 4

 

  • The correct statements drawn from the values given in the table are 3 and 4.
  • An odds ratio is a measure of the association between an exposure and an outcome. It represents the odds that an outcome will occur given a particular exposure in comparison to the odds of the outcome occurring in the absence of that exposure.

 

Statement 3: Risk of developing blindness increases with age.

 

  • Correct. The odds ratios increase with age categories, and all are statistically significant with p-values <0.001. This indicates that the risk of developing blindness increases with age.

 

Statement 4: Illiteracy leads to increased risk of developing blindness.

 

  • Correct. The odds ratio for illiteracy is 1.2 with a p-value <0.01, indicating that illiteracy is associated with an increased risk of developing blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Statements 1 and 2 have an odds ratio of >1 and a statistically significant p-value, respectively. This implies that the cause increases the risk of disease and is a risk factor. However, these statements are incorrect due to the following reason: -

 

Statement 1: Female population is at greater risk of developing blindness is a false statement; since the odds ratio is <1, the female population will be at lesser risk of developing blindness than the male population.

 

Statement 2: People dwelling in rural areas are at increased risk of developing blindness is also false; a p-value of >0.05 means that this association is not statistically significant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Odds ratio interpretation:

 

  • Odds ratio of 1: Indicates that the risk factor is not related to the disease.
  • Odds ratio less than 1: Indicates that a person with the disease is less likely to have been exposed to the factor, implying that the factor may be protective.
  • Odds ratio greater than 1: Indicates that the factor is associated with an increased risk of the disease.

 

p-value interpretation:

 

  • p-value < 0.05: Indicates that the result is statistically significant.
  • p-value > 0.05: Indicates that the result is not statistically significant.

questions.text: Arrange the steps of the Disaster cycle in sequence. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disaster impact – Response – Rehabilitation – Mitigation  

 

The disaster cycle outlines the sequential steps taken in response to a disaster and how communities can prepare and recover from such events. The correct sequence is:

 

  1. Disaster Impact: This is the immediate occurrence of the disaster event, such as an earthquake, flood, or hurricane, leading to direct damage and disruption.
  2. Response: Following the impact, emergency measures are taken to save lives, provide first aid, conduct search and rescue, and offer immediate relief such as food, shelter, and medical treatment.
  3. Rehabilitation: After the initial response, efforts shift to restoring essential services and helping affected communities return to normal. This involves rebuilding infrastructure, ensuring public health, and restoring social and economic activities.
  4. Mitigation: This final step involves implementing measures to reduce the severity of future disasters. This can include building stronger infrastructure, improving disaster preparedness plans, and promoting community awareness to minimize potential damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the disaster cycle is: Disaster Impact → Response → Rehabilitation → Mitigation.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). According to the World Health Organization's guidelines, which of the following treatment schedules is recommended? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 7 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 5 months

 

  • WHO defines Multi-drug resistant (MDR) Tuberculosis strain as Resistant to INH and Rifampicin with or without resistant to other anti TB drugs

 

Treatment of MDR-TB:

 

  • DOTS PLUS (Older name: Category IV)
  • Must be done on basis of sensitivity testing
  • Directly observed therapy certainly helps to improve outcomes and is considered an integral part of MDR-TB treatment
    • The recommended treatment regimen for multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) involves a two-phase approach.
    • In the initial phase, patients are prescribed a combination of seven drugs for a duration of 4 to 6 months. These seven drugs are collectively referred to as CHOBZEE, which stands for Clofazimine, High dose Isoniazid, Levofloxacin, Bedaquiline, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol, and Ethionamide.
    • Following the initial phase, the treatment enters a second phase where four drugs are continued for an additional 5 months. These four drugs are collectively known as COZE, consisting of Clofazimine, Levofloxacin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol. Note: Bedaquiline is always given for 6 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

New Regimens for Treatment Drug Resistant TB (RNTCP 2017-18)

 

 

(Drugs: Hh: High dose isoniazid; E:Ethambutol; Z:Pyrazinamide; K:Kanamycin; Cm: Capreomycin; A Amikacin; L: Levofloxacin; M: Moxifloxacin; Mh: High dose moxifloxacin; Et; Ethionamide; Cs: Cycloserine; Cz: Clofazimine; Lz: Linezolid; Bq: Bedaquiline

questions.text: In a community, there were 550 births in a year out of which 50 were stillbirths. There were 09 deaths among newborns during 0-7 days of life. An additional 41 deaths occurred during 8-28 days of life. Calculate the Early Neonatal Mortality rate for the given community. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 18

 

The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR) measures the number of deaths of newborns within the first 7 days of life per 1,000 live births. It focuses specifically on early neonatal deaths, which occur during the first week of life.

 

Calculation:

 

  • Total births: 550
  • Stillbirths: 50
  • Live births (LB): 550 - 50 = 500
  • Early Neonatal Deaths (ENND): 9 deaths during 0-7 days.

 

ENMR formula:

 

 

Therefore, the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is 18 deaths per 1,000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is calculated as the number of early neonatal deaths (0-7 days) per 1,000 live births.
