IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets
2 iron and folic acid tablets OD + IV iron sucrose

questions.text: A pregnant woman presenting at less than 34 weeks of gestation displays signs of mild to moderate anemia. Under the "Anemia Mukh Bharat" initiative, which therapeutic approach would be the most appropriate? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets

 

The best treatment among the given options is IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets.

 

Severity of Anemia according to Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign,

 

  • Mild – 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate – 7-9 g%
  • Severe – <7 g %

 

Testing and treating Mild and Moderate Anemia:

 

  • If mild anemia OR moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron and folic acid
  • If patient presents late in pregnancy or is unable to tolerate oral iron: Parenteral iron – IV Iron sucrose or Ferric carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe anemia:

 

  • Hb < 7g%: Parenteral iron – IV Iron sucrose or Ferric carboxymaltose (FeCM).
  • If patient presents late in the third trimester with severe anemia or Hb is less than 5 g%: ADMIT

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anemia Mukt Bharat (2018)

 

Aim: Reduce anemia by 3% per year

 

6 x 6 x 6 strategy

questions.text: What is the latest online software introduced by the government under the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP) to monitor patients with tuberculosis? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) NIKSHAY

 

  • NIKSHAY is the latest online software introduced by the Indian government under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) to monitor and manage patients with tuberculosis. This software facilitates the tracking of TB patients from diagnosis through treatment, ensuring that all cases are adequately monitored to achieve the goal of TB elimination.
  • NIKSHAY (Nikshay) aims to improve the surveillance, monitoring, and treatment of TB patients by providing a centralized platform for data collection and management. It enables health workers to record details of TB cases, track patient progress, and ensure that treatment protocols are followed, which is crucial for the effective management of TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NISCHAY:   This refers to a pregnancy test kit and is unrelated to the monitoring of TB patients.

 

Option C. E-DOTS:  Electronic Directly Observed Therapy (eDOT) aka Virtual Directly Observed Therapy, is an approach for treating TB where healthcare providers observe patients taking their medication through real-time or prerecorded video.

 

Option D. NIKUSTH:  This software is used for monitoring leprosy patients, not tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NIKSHAY - Monitoring TB patients.

 

NIKUSTH - Monitoring leprosy patients.

                                          

NISCHAY - Pregnancy test kit.

 

E-DOTS - Virtual Directly Observed Therapy DOT.

questions.text: A case of trauma presents to the Emergency with an unknown blood group. Since the patient was hemodynamically unstable, he required immediate blood transfusion. Which blood type can be transfused? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) O positive and O negative

 

In emergency situations where the patient's blood group is unknown, and immediate blood transfusion is required, O negative blood is preferred because it is known as the universal donor. O negative blood can be transfused to any patient regardless of their blood type since it lacks A, B, and Rh antigens, minimizing the risk of adverse reactions.

 

However, if O negative blood is not available, O positive blood can be used, especially in life-threatening situations. While O positive is not universally compatible like O negative, it is still relatively safe for transfusion in emergencies, particularly in patients who are male or non-childbearing females, where the risks of Rh incompatibility are lower.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A positive and O negative: A positive blood can only be given to A positive or AB positive recipients. It is not suitable for unknown blood types in emergencies.

 

Option B. AB negative and O negative: AB negative blood is not a universal donor; it can only be given to AB negative recipients.

 

Option D. A positive and O positive: Similar to option A, A positive is not universally compatible and is therefore not ideal in emergency situations where the blood type is unknown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Universal blood donor and the safest option: O negative.

questions.text: In the context of the health belief model, a medical student is reviewing its different components. One of the boxes, labeled "C", is described as the individual's willingness to act on their beliefs regarding health threats and the benefits of taking preventive action. Which of the following best represents box C? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Health motivation

 

  • Box C stands for health motivation.
  • This represents the individual's readiness and willingness to engage in health-promoting behaviors.
  • This motivation influences how individuals perceive their susceptibility and severity of health issues, as well as the benefits and barriers to taking action.

 

 

The health belief model was proposed from the idea that a person's health behaviour changes in accordance with certain beliefs.

 

It can be categorized as follows:

 

  • Individual perceptions.
  • Variable factors that modify beliefs.
  • Action.

 

Individual perceptions:

 

Perceived susceptibility refers to a person's own beliefs about the probability of developing a disease. If the perceived susceptibility is high, an individual is more likely to engage in health-promoting behaviour to reduce the chances of contracting the illness.

 

Perceived severity is an individual's assessment of the severity of a particular health problem. If the disease is perceived to have a high severity, then the person is more likely to adopt a healthier lifestyle. Perceived threat comprises perceived susceptibility and severity. People with a higher perceived threat tend to take on health-promoting activities.

 

Action:

 

Perceived benefits refer to a person's subjective judgment on how a particular health habit is modifying his chances of developing a disease. If the person believes that a habit is likely to reduce his/her chances of susceptibility to a disease or lower the severity of a disease, he/she is more likely to follow that healthy habit.

 

Perceived barriers to action also influence if a person wants to follow healthy behaviour. The benefits of a particular health habit must overweigh the barriers that a person must overcome to continue following that behaviour.

 

Cues to action may be internal or external. Internal cues include pain and clinical symptoms. External cues include awareness through media, physicians, and friends.

 

The health belief system is thought to be useful in analyzing health behaviour patterns and formulating disease prevention plans based on these beliefs. All internal and external factors, including demographic and psychological characteristics, aim at health motivation to attain the action phase of a health belief system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perceived control: Perceived control refers to a person's internal belief in the control they would have over things that are part of the past or the future or over a process, behavior, and outcome. Perceived control can influence all of the categories of the health belief system.

 

Option B. Behavioral modification: Behavioral modification is part of the action after assessing all of the above-mentioned concepts.

 

Option D. Self-efficacy: Self-efficacy can be defined as a person's capacity in achieving his health goals. A person's confidence in his/her ability to overcome limitations to attain his/her health goals was found to be a major factor in determining the outcome of his behavioral changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the health belief model, health motivation (Box C) represents an individual's willingness to act on their health beliefs regarding susceptibility, severity, benefits, and barriers to take preventive health actions.

questions.text: Which virus outbreak occurred in Kerala following consumption of date palm sap? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nipah virus

 

Explanation:

 

The Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala was linked to the consumption of fruits contaminated with bat secretions. Date palm sap, which is a popular drink in the region, can become contaminated with bat secretions containing the Nipah virus when bats feed on the sap. Consumption of this contaminated sap led to the Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ebola virus transmission occurs through contact with contaminated body fluids from infected individuals. It is not associated with the consumption of date palm sap or fruits.

 

Option C. Litchi Virus Disease, also known as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES), has been reported in West Bengal. It is linked to the consumption of litchis on an empty stomach by children, which can lead to severe hypoglycemia and death due to the generation of methylenecyclopropylglycine (MCPG).

 

Option D. West Nile Fever, transmitted by the Culex pipiens mosquito, has been reported in Kerala.

 

Note - Although a single case of Ebola virus was reported at the Delhi International Airport, it is not related to the Kerala outbreak caused by the consumption of date palm sap.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala was linked to the consumption of date palm sap contaminated with bat secretions containing the virus.

questions.text: What is the test of significance conducted for two or more proportions? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi-square test

 

The Chi-square test is used to determine if there is a significant association between categorical variables. It is especially useful for testing the relationship between two or more proportions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Student's test: This typically refers to the t-test, which is used to compare means between two groups. It is not appropriate for proportions.

 

Option C. Z test: While the Z test can be used for proportions, it is usually employed for large sample sizes and comparing the means of two populations.

 

Option D. ANOVA: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) is used to compare the means among three or more groups, not for comparing proportions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A couple from a rural village in Rajasthan is expecting their first child and seeks to start regular health check-ups for the expectant mother at a nearby government health facility. What is the appropriate first point of contact for seeking medical care in their community? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Subcentre

 

Ideal first contact for people seeking medical care in a community is a Subcentre.

 

 

Levels of Primary Health Care System in India

 

  • Primary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘first level of contact between population and health care system’ in India
    • Health services are delivered through - Sub-centre and Primary Health Centre
  • Secondary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘First referral level of health care’ in India
    • Health services are delivered through: Community Health Centre
  • Tertiary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘Second referral level of health care’ in India
    • Health services are delivered through: Medical Colleges and Hospitals

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a couple in a rural village, a Subcentre is the most accessible and relevant first point of care, offering essential health services and initial check-ups for pregnant women, thus ensuring early and regular monitoring throughout pregnancy.

questions.text: Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is: [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) All of the above

 

Explanation

 

All listed infections—Chickenpox, Rubella, and CMV (Cytomegalovirus)—can potentially lead to teratogenic effects if a mother contracts them during pregnancy. Here's a brief explanation of how each can impact fetal development:

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Chickenpox: Infection in early pregnancy can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which includes skin scarring, limb abnormalities, and neurologic disorders.

 

Option B. Rubella: Known for its teratogenic potential if contracted in the first trimester; can cause congenital rubella syndrome, leading to cataracts, deafness, heart defects, and neurological damage.

 

Option C. CMV: The most common viral cause of congenital infections leading to developmental disabilities, including hearing loss, vision loss, and neurodevelopmental disorders.

 

Educational objective :

 

Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is : TORCH infection

 

  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Other (includes infections such as Syphilis, Varicella-Zoster, Parvovirus B19, and Zika virus)
  • Rubella
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)

 

Note – Now, also includes – Treponema pallidum, HIV, Hep. B viruses

questions.text: What is the SI unit used to measure the brightness of light from a point source among the options provided? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Candela

 

The candela is the SI unit used to measure the brightness (luminous intensity) of a light source emitting light in a specific direction. It quantifies the amount of light emitted from a point source within a solid angle of one steradian.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lux: Usage: Measures illumination or illuminance.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the amount of light reaching a surface. One lux is equal to one lumen per square meter.

 

Option C. Lambert: Usage: Measures brightness or luminance.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the amount of light emitted by a surface. One lambert is equal to the luminance of a surface emitting or reflecting one lumen per square centimeter.

 

Option D. Lumen: Usage: Measures luminous flux.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the total amount of visible light emitted by a source. One lumen is the luminous flux emitted within a solid angle of one steradian by a point source with a luminous intensity of one candela.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is admitted with dengue hemorrhagic fever. After several days of management, her condition stabilizes, and the medical team considers discharging her. Which of the following is an appropriate criterion to decide the discharge of a patient recovering from dengue hemorrhagic shock? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) After the return of appetite

 

  • The appropriate criteria for discharging a patient recovering from dengue hemorrhagic shock include several clinical signs indicating recovery and stability.
  • One crucial criterion is the return of appetite, which signifies a significant clinical improvement and recovery from the acute phase of the illness.

 

SIGNS OF RECOVERY: 

 

  • Stable pulse, blood pressure and breathing rate
  • Normal temperature
  • No evidence of external or internal bleeding
  • Return of appetite
  • No vomiting
  • Good urine output 
  • Stable haematocrit 
  • Convalescent confluent petechiae rash

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol: The absence of fever should be without the use of antipyretics like paracetamol.

 

Option C. Urine output more than 200 ml: This is not a standard criterion; adequate urine output should be considered, but specific volume thresholds are not typically used.

 

Option D. After 24 hours from recovery of shock: Recovery from shock should be sustained, and other criteria like appetite and clinical stability are more reliable indicators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRITERIA FOR DISCHARGING PATIENTS: 

 

  • Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of anti-fever therapy
  • Return of appetite
  • Visible clinical improvement 
  • Good urine output 
  • Minimum of three days after recovery from shock
  • No respiratory distress from pleural effusion and no ascites
  • Platelet count of more than 50,000/mm

questions.text: Cytotoxic and expired medications are appropriately discarded through: [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incineration

 

  • Expired and cytotoxic drugs should be disposed of using specific methods, such as incineration, encapsulation, or plasma pyrolysis, and should be returned to the manufacturer if possible.
  • Other medications can also be disposed of using similar methods.
  • The use of yellow bags is common for hazardous waste to ensure proper handling and disposal by trained personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The patient should undergo another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition.
There is a 2% prevalence of the disease in the population.
It is less likely that the patient has the disease.
The patient has been mistakenly ruled out due to a false negative result.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of persistent fatigue. The physician is concerned about a particular condition and orders an on-site diagnostic test to evaluate further. The test, known to have a sensitivity of 98%, returns a negative result. Based on the high sensitivity, what is the most likely implication of this negative test outcome for the patient? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It is less likely that the patient has the disease. 

 

  • A negative result in a diagnostic test with a sensitivity of 98% implies that the patient is less likely to have the disease.
  • Sensitivity is the proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • It is the probability of the test being positive when the disease is present.
  • The sensitivity of a test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total diseased population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The patient should undergo another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition: The patient would not need another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition as the sensitivity of the diagnostic test is 98%.

 

Option B. There is a 2% prevalence of the disease in the population: Prevalence refers to the number of old and new cases at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It cannot be derived from the given data.

 

Option D. The patient has been mistakenly ruled out due to a false negative result: The higher the sensitivity of a diagnostic test, the lower will be the number of false negatives. Since the test has a 98% sensitivity, the patient most likely does not have the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A negative result in a highly sensitive test (98% sensitivity) makes it very unlikely that the patient has the disease, as false negatives are rare with such tests.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a study that is longitudinal, observational, and includes the analysis of variables to determine associations? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

Explanation:

 

  • The correct term for a longitudinal, observational study that involves the analysis of variables to determine associations among a group of people is a "cohort study”.
  • In a cohort study, participants are followed over time to see how different exposures affect their chances of developing an outcome. 
  • It's useful for studying the effects of suspected risk factors that cannot be controlled experimentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-Control Study: This type of study involves identifying participants based on the presence (case) or absence (control) of a particular outcome or disease and then looking back retrospectively to compare exposure to a risk factor or intervention between the groups.

 

Option C. Ecological Study: These studies assess risk factors or outcomes in a population based on data at the group level, rather than individual data. It's useful for initial, broad correlations between environmental or contextual factors and health outcomes.

 

Option D. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): This is an experimental study where participants are randomly assigned to either the group receiving the intervention or to a control group that does not, to compare outcomes in a controlled way.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For analyzing how various factors might affect health outcomes over time within a specified group, a cohort study is typically the most appropriate method due to its ability to follow participants through time and observe changes and outcomes as they occur naturally.

questions.text: The following are the phases of:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Demographic process

 

Explanation:

 

Demography is the scientific study of human populations, and demographic processes are the key factors that influence population dynamics. The five main demographic processes mentioned in the image are:

 

  1. Fertility: Related to childbirth and reproduction
  2. Mortality: Related to deaths and life expectancy
  3. Marriage: Formation and dissolution of marital unions
  4. Migration: Physical or geographical movement of people from one place to another
  5. Social mobility: Movement of individuals across social classes or socio-economic status

 

These processes collectively determine the size, structure, and distribution of populations over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Demographic dividend: This refers to the economic growth potential resulting from a population's changing age structure, typically when the working-age population is larger than the non-working-age population. It is not directly related to the five processes listed.

 

Option C. Demographic cycle: Also known as the demographic transition model, this describes the stages a population goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. While related to demographic processes, the stages of the demographic cycle are not the same as the processes listed.

 

Option D. Human Development Index (HDI): This is a composite statistic developed by the United Nations to measure and rank countries' levels of social and economic development. It takes into account life expectancy, education, and per capita income. HDI is not directly related to the five demographic processes mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fertility, mortality, marriage, migration, and social mobility are the five main demographic processes that influence population dynamics and are studied in the field of demography.

questions.text: Dose for a new drug is assessed in which phase of Clinical trial? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Phase 1

 

Phase 1: This phase involves testing the drug on a small number of healthy human volunteers. The primary objective is to evaluate the drug's safety profile, non-toxicity, and determine the appropriate dosage range. Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) is often calculated in this phase, which makes it crucial for dose assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phase 2: Phase 2 clinical trials are designed to assess the efficacy of a drug or treatment. These trials involve a larger group of participants (100) than Phase 1 and aim to provide preliminary data on whether the drug works in people who have a certain condition or disease. Phase 2 trials also continue to monitor the drug's safety and side effects.

 

Option C. Phase 3: Phase 3 trials are conducted on a larger scale to confirm the drug's efficacy, monitor side effects, compare it to commonly used treatments, and collect information that will allow the drug to be used safely. These trials involve a larger number of participants and provide the critical data needed for regulatory approval. Drugs launched post this phase.

 

Option D. Phase 4: Phase 4 trials occur after the drug has been approved for use by the FDA. These post-marketing studies monitor the long-term effectiveness and impact on the general population, including any rare or long-term side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Remove IUD gently, then do MTP

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman had an IUD inserted at a PHC. After a few months, she conceives. On examination, the IUD is still in place. She wants to continue with her pregnancy. Next best step of management is? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Remove IUD gently

 

In cases where a woman becomes pregnant with an intrauterine device (IUD) still in place and wishes to continue with the pregnancy, the standard approach is to gently remove the IUD if the threads are visible and accessible. Removal of the IUD reduces the risk of complications such as infection, preterm labor, and spontaneous abortion. Gently pulling the IUD threads minimizes trauma and associated risks.

 

However, it is important to counsel the patient about the increased risk of spontaneous abortion even after the removal of the IUD, but removal is generally recommended to avoid ongoing complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove IUD gently, then do MTP: This is incorrect because performing Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) is not mandatory and cannot be enforced unless the patient chooses it. The primary goal here is to safely remove the IUD, not to proceed directly with MTP.

 

Option C. Do MTP directly: This option is incorrect because the patient explicitly wants to continue the pregnancy. MTP should not be performed without the patient’s consent, and it is not a management step in this case unless requested by the patient.

 

Option D. Leave IUD in situ: Leaving the IUD in place is not advisable as it poses a high risk of adverse outcomes, including infections, miscarriage, and preterm birth. The safest option is to remove the IUD if possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If a woman conceives with an IUD in place and wishes to continue the pregnancy, the IUD should be gently removed to minimize the risk of complications.

questions.text: What is the term for the likelihood that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Positive predictive value

 

Positive predictive value tells that that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question.

 

 

  • ‘a’ are known as True positive (TP): Population having the disease and showing screening test results as positive
  • ‘d’ are known as True negative (TN): Population not having the disease and showing screening test results as negative
  • ‘b’ are known as False positive (FP): Population not having the disease but erroneously showing screening test results as positive
  • ‘c’ are known as False negative (FN): Population having the disease but erroneously showing screening test results as negative

 

Positive predictive value (PPV): Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, out of all those who test positive on a screening test
PPV = a/ (a + b) × 100 = TP/ (TP + FP) × 100

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensitivity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease (cases)
Sensitivity = a/ (a + c) × 100 = TP/ (TP + FN) × 100

 

Option B. Specificity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease (healthy)
Specificity = d/ (b + d) × 100 = TN/ (TN + FP) × 100

 

Option D. Negative predictive value (NPV): Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease, out of all those who test negative on a screening test
NPV = d/ (c + d) × 100 = TN/ (FN + TN) × 100

 

Educational Objective:

 

Positive predictive value (PPV) is the measure that indicates the likelihood that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question. It is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of a screening test in correctly identifying true positive cases.

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for managing the school health programs? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Primary health center

 

  • In India, the School Health Committee recommended that school health services be integrated with general health services, which are managed by primary health centers (PHCs).
  • To ensure effective implementation, the committee proposed the formation of school health committees at various levels. PHCs are responsible for providing a range of school health services such as health assessments, vision and hearing tests, dental check-ups, treatment for common illnesses, immunization, micronutrient management, deworming, and provision of mid-day meals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary Health Centers (PHCs) are responsible for managing school health programs in India, providing a range of health services to ensure the well-being of school children.

questions.text: Water has accumulated in a container from a malfunctioning septic system, and mosquito larvae are observed. Based on the provided larval image, which mosquito species is it likely to be? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Culex

 

Culex mosquito breeds in dirty water. The image shows a Culex larva with head suspended downwards at an angle to water surface and a siphon tube.

 

  • In Culex, siphon tube is long and narrow
  • In Aedes, it is short and broad
  • In Mansonia, larvae are attached through siphon tube to roots of aquatic plants
  • In Anopheles- No siphon tube but only apertures on 8thabdominal segment

 

Breeding Habitant

 

Anopheles → Sophisticated Mosquito; Breeds in clean water

 

Culex → Nuisance Mosquito; Breeds in dirty water

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to a clinic in a developing region after receiving the MMR vaccination as part of a mass immunization program. Supplemental vitamin A is given alongside the vaccination. What is the appropriate dose of vitamin A to be given immediately after the MMR vaccination and then on the following day? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1,00,000 IU

 

Vitamin A is given along with MMR vaccine at 9 months of age at a dose of 1 lakh IU.

 

Dosage of Vitamin A as per age:

 

< 6 Month – 50,000 IU orally

6-12 Months – 1,00,000 IU orally

Above 12 Months – 2,00,000 IU orally

 

Educational Objective:

 

For children aged 6-12 months, the appropriate dose of vitamin A supplementation given alongside the MMR vaccine is 1,00,000 IU.

choices.text: Normal distribution, evident outliers, negative skewness, positive skewness
Evident positive skewness, normal distribution, negative skewness, outliers present
Binominal distribution, outliers present, skewed negatively, skewed positively
Standard distribution, outliers present, evident positive skewness, negative skewness

questions.text: A hospital biostatistician analyzes patient wait times over several months to find patterns and outliers for optimizing patient flow. After analyzing four different months, the following box plots are created to illustrate the findings. Based on the given plots, match the correct description? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Normal distribution, evident outliers, negative skewness, positive skewness

 

  1. Plot 1 – Normal distribution
    • The box is roughly centered with whiskers of nearly equal length on both sides and no extreme values. This symmetry and lack of outliers indicate an approximately normal spread of wait times.
  2. Plot 2 – Evident outliers
    • Two data points lie clearly beyond the upper whisker (marked in red). These are outliers, while the central box and whiskers remain fairly symmetric.
  3. Plot 3 – Negative skewness
    • The lower whisker (toward shorter wait times) is substantially longer than the upper whisker, and the median line sits above the box’s center. This shows a left (negative) skew, where a few very short waits pull the lower tail.
  4. Plot 4 – Positive skewness
    • The upper whisker (toward longer wait times) is longer than the lower whisker, and the median is below the box’s center. This pattern reflects a right (positive) skew, due to some unusually long waits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Box and whisker plot 

 

  • Description: A convenient way of graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles 
  • Edges of box: 1st and 3rd Quartile 
  • Line in Box: 2nd Quartile (Median) 
  • Whiskers end: Minimum & maximum values 
  • Outlier: A data point that is located outside the whiskers of the box plot

questions.text: In a given population, total births were 4050 including 50 stillbirths in a given year. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life, and an additional 150 die within 8-28 days of life. What is the Neonatal mortality rate in the population? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50

 

The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is a key indicator of neonatal health and is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths per 1000 live births. The neonatal period spans from birth up to 28 days and is further divided into:

 

  • Early Neonatal Period: 0-7 days
  • Late Neonatal Period: 8-28 days

 

Calculation:

 

  • Total births: 4050 (including 50 stillbirths)
  • Neonatal deaths:
    • Early Neonatal Period: 50 deaths
    • Late Neonatal Period: 150 deaths
  • Total Neonatal Deaths: 50 + 150 = 200 deaths
  • Total Live Births: 4050 - 50 (stillbirths) = 4000 live births
  • Neonatal Mortality Rate Formula:

 

 

  • Calculate NMR

 

 

Thus, the Ans.  is 50 per 1000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths per 1000 live births.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company is in the early stages of developing a new antihypertensive medication. They are planning to conduct several phases of clinical trials to assess different aspects of the drug. As part of this process, the research team is set to embark on Phase 1 of the trial. In the context of clinical trial phases, what is the primary objective of this initial phase? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Safety 

 

  • Phase 1 of clinical trials is critically important as it marks the first introduction of a new drug into human subjects.
  • The primary focus during this phase is to evaluate the safety of the drug.

 

Key elements assessed in Phase 1 include:

 

  • Safety & Non-toxicity.
  • Maximum Tolerated Dose (MTD.

 

Educational Objective:
